data.title: Allow extension commands to define the behaviour when Alt modifier is pressed
data.body:
When you declare a `command` for an extension, it appears in `Command Palette` and you can select/use it with `Return Key`/`Mouse Click`. But there are some _core commands_ that has _special behavior_ when you combine with `Ctrl`, like `Open on the Side`.

I would like to have the ability to declare a command and have the _normal_ and _alternative_ behaviors, just like that. 

Thanks in advance

data.title: Only apply TS Dot Accept Suggestion if Previous Character is a valid identifier
data.body:
Fixes #17825
Fixes #17770
Fixes #17584

**Bug**
When typing two or more `.` in a row, we end up unexpectedly accepting suggestions in TS files. This is caused by the custom keybinding that ts registers for `.`.

**Fix**
Only accept the suggestion on `.` if the previous character is a valid identifier character. This is accomplished by registering a new command in TS. 

I'm not too happy with this workaround, but wasn't able to find a better way to do this. Let me know if you have any suggested improvements.

data.title: App won‘t launch on macOS from user-specific ~/Applications directory

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.9.0-insider
- OS Version: macOS Sierra 10.12.2

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Download and extract insider build
2. Move application bundle to ~/Applications
3. Launch Visual Studio Code.app
4. Launch does not complete. Full menu bar and main window do not appear.

Workaround:

- After moving the bundle from user-specific ~/Applications to system-wide /Applications, application launches.

data.title: Use TS 2.1.4 To Build VSCode
data.body: Updates from using TS 2.0.3 to using TS 2.1.4 to builds VSCode. This required a few small changes to fix breaking changes with TS. I also picked up `typescript-formatter` 4.0.1

data.title: View > Explorer, keyboard shortcut not working (Mac)
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.8.1 (ee428b0eead68bf0fb99ab5fdc4439be227b6281, 2016-12-19T14:42:49.304Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 15.6.0
- Extensions:

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|material-icon-theme|PKief|1.2.0|
|vscode-html-to-elm|Rubymaniac|0.0.2|
|elm-format|abadi199|0.1.0|
|elm|sbrink|0.8.3|
|vim|vscodevim|0.4.10|

---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Navigate away from Explorer view by clicking on, say, Extensions icon, or typing `shift+cmd+x`
2. Attempt to navigate back to Explorer by typing `shift+cmd+e` as indicated in keybindings.json
   No reaction visible in menu or in current view
3. Open keyboard shortcuts with `cmd+k cmd+s`
4. Customize the View > Explorer shortcut, e.g., `{ "key": "shift+ctrl+e",           "command": "workbench.view.explorer" }`
5. Try the new shortcut, e.g., `shift+ctrl+e`
   > View switches to Explorer, proving that View > Explorer can be accessed with a keyboard shortcut, just not `shift+cmd+e`.
6. Open System Preferences > Keyboard > Shortcuts. Verify that there are no system-level conflicts for ⇧⌘E.

data.title: Go to next/previous (git) change

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body: Recently I've been wanting to jump to the next git change/add/delete more and more similar to how F8 will jump to the next problem. I can't find a command for doing this but it would keep my hand off the mouse an awful lot more, especially in large files where scrolling via the scrollbar is not so accurate.

data.title: Evaluate selected expression on hover while debugging?

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
_This is a feature request._

Would it be possible to add the feature of evaluating a highlighted JS expression on hover while debugging? This is something that was recently added to Chrome DevTools and is very useful. It would be nice to have this same feature added to VS Code as well.

### Hovering over a single variable (works in VS Code):
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3431954/21621155/62843030-d1bd-11e6-8174-2c6a005e3c93.png)

### Hovering over a highlighted expression (doesn't work in VS Code):
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3431954/21621178/79fa08e8-d1bd-11e6-8031-092c64ab4693.png)

Thanks!

data.title: failed to execute git
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.9.0-insider (f2379e882b415e2c503a723776c4431a40d7c1aa, 2017-01-02T07:11:43.247Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.14393

|PowerShell|ms-vscode|0.8.0|
|Chef|Pendrica|0.6.2|
|code-settings-sync|Shan|2.4.1|

---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. vscode (latest and latest insiders) open any git repo. Git works from my path and can be called no problem
2. opening GIT from sidebar just keeps scrolling and times out, never any output at all. 

ran 'show developer tools' and got this 


pretty confused.

Hi everybody.

Currently `CodeLens` accepts a position, but it doesn't use it.

Let's look at the code:
```c
int main() {
    int a = 5 + 10;
               ^ Here is code lens
}
```

Regards,
Alexey

data.title: Quick Open does not find files behind a symbolic link (Windows)
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.9.0-insider (d384271ffb5655cee1ddf8f93f51cd892ee2cc40, 2017-01-03T07:10:03.605Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.14986
- Extensions:

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|vscode-eslint|dbaeumer|1.2.2|
|theme-dracula|dracula-theme|1.2.5|
|gitlens|eamodio|1.4.0|
|vscode-great-icons|emmanuelbeziat|1.1.35|
|theme-material-theme|jprestidge|1.0.1|
|vs-color-picker|lihui|0.3.2|
|Theme-MaterialKit|ms-vscode|0.1.1|
|view-in-browser|qinjia|0.0.3|
|eval|Stormspirit|0.0.5|

---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open a directory containing a symbolic link from vscode
2. Press ctrl+p and type something with matches inside the symbolic link

What happens:

The matches inside the symbolic link do not appear.

Once the file has been manually opened (from the VSCode Explorer), they will appear as "recently opened".

Note that I wasn't able to reproduce it with a simple project, but this happens with this one:

![problemquickopen](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/199648/21612576/19caa7ec-d1d2-11e6-80bb-de71fd982d40.png)

Here "statics" is a symlink (created with mklink /D) which should contain a brief.css file), so the full path should be: `yo\engine\app\statics\stylesheets\OnMap\brief.css` (as highlighted in the vscode explorer) but this file doesn't appear in the quickpanel.

If if double click to open it from the explorer, doing a quick search will make it appear into the quick open panel:

![vscodeafteropeningfile](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/199648/21612544/f51423e2-d1d1-11e6-802d-108b44d9e0fa.png)

data.title: Expose Typescript insertSpaceAfterOpeningAndBeforeClosingNonemptyBraces rule in VS Code settings
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.8.1
- OS Version: Linux

Typescript has the `insertSpaceAfterOpeningAndBeforeClosingNonemptyBraces` rule, but this rule cannot be configured in the VS Code settings.

Please add
`javascript.format.insertSpaceAfterOpeningAndBeforeClosingNonemptyBraces`
and
`typescript.format.insertSpaceAfterOpeningAndBeforeClosingNonemptyBraces`
to the VS Code settings, to be able to prevent `{key: 'value'}` being changed to `{ key: 'value' }` when formatting

Thanks!

data.title: Separate themes from other extensions

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
Themes are not really an extension, much like a font change isn't an extension and when one has more than a few themes, the extension panel becomes very confusing/cluttered.

Proposal: introduce different panel/page where I can search, activate, add and remove themes, without the confusion of having other extensions added to the page. Also this would improve UX after installing a theme, because the proper theme wouldn't be lost in the extensions list on editor reload - for example when I want to remove it right away.

- VSCode Version: Code 1.8.1 (ee428b0eead68bf0fb99ab5fdc4439be227b6281, 2016-12-19T14:49:23.350Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.14393

Say I am trying to find a theme, where I can actually read the tab labels (most are dark grey on slightly darker background and there is no theme customization) and need to try tens of themes, each time going through this reload-confirm-uninstall routine.

I move to remove the dialog, as is doesn't seem to serve any purpose. (regardless of my specific use case)

data.title: Possible to save file multiple times leads to race condition
data.body:
When auto save is disabled and you work against a slow network share where save takes longer, it is possible to save a file multiple times with different contents leading to bad race conditions where you sporadically see warnings about the contents on disk being newer.

Part of https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/13665

data.title: Change pointer to default as cursor when hovering over items in the program
data.body:
- VSCode Version: All versions
- OS Version: All versions

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Hover over an actionable item, and notice how your cursor changes to a Hand.

Also notice how in nearly all desktop software, you do not get this behavior. Instead, the actionable item slightly changes to indicate that the user is hovering over it. But in VS Code, this is not the case. The cursor is changed to convey this. Changing to a hand cursor leaves a very web-ish and uncomfortable feeling, and even though this is technically based on web technologies, it is still a "desktop app", and I believe that the behavior should be consistent with the rest of the system and its software.

I have already "fixed" this in my fork and would like to push a PR. What do you think?

data.title: How to perform telemetry for extensions
data.body:
I want to get a report of currently users online or used my extension recently, filtering them by locations and other many things.
is there any way to do that ?
